bestBHT.bht: The lake of fire awaits those who are not found written in the book of life, leaving no room for soul sleeping, an intermediate state, second chances, or the annihilation of the wicked. This judgment is specific to the destiny of the wicked and it signifies their ultimate destruction. It reminds us that only those who have their names recorded in the book of life will experience the blissful lot of the righteous, which has already commenced before the final judgment.

Henry Alford: And if any was not found written in the book of life, he was cast into the lake of fire (there was no intermediate state).
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: righteous is not here specially mentioned as their bliss had
commenced before the final judgment. Compare, however, Matthew 25:34;
Albert Barnes: (1) "No word could be more comprehensive than this.
(2) "They will be alike in the only thing on which their eternal destiny will depend - that they have not so lived that their names have become recorded in the book of life.
(3) "The wicked will be destroyed, in what may be properly called the 'second' death.
Marvin Vincent: And whosoever [ει τις] . Lit., if any. So Rev.
Philip Schaff: The judgment now described is not a general judgment, but one on the wicked only.
The passage, as a whole, is occupied with judgment upon the enemies of the Church.
In the vision now before us we have a judgment of the wicked, and not a general judgment.
Archibald T. Robertson: In this short sentence the doom is told of all who are out of Christ, for they too follow the devil and the two beasts into the lake of fire.
There is no room here for soul sleeping, for an intermediate state, for a second chance, or for annihilation of the wicked.
In Daniel 12:2 there is a resurrection to death as well as to life and so in John 5:29; Acts 24:15.
John Gill: Woe to the wicked, who are not written in the book, for they shall perish in hell for ever and ever.
In the writing of eternal life, which is written for the righteous of the house of Israel, they shall not be written.
Let it be cast into the salt sea, or the bituminous lake.

bhtAttempts.bht: Those whose names are not found written in the book of life are cast into the lake of fire without an intermediate state. This verse emphasizes the eternal fate of those who are outside of Christ, as they follow the devil and the two beasts into the lake of fire. There is no room for theories of soul sleeping, an intermediate state, a second chance, or annihilation of the wicked. This judgment is specifically on the wicked, not a general judgment, and it is the final destruction for those who are not recorded in the book of life.

Those who are not found written in the book of life are cast into the lake of fire, signifying the eternal fate of those outside of Christ. This judgment is the final destruction for the wicked, without an intermediate state or a second chance. It is a sober reminder that there is no room for theories of soul sleeping or annihilation. The emphasis here is on the eternal destiny of those who follow the devil and the two beasts into the lake of fire.

Those whose names are not recorded in the book of life face the dreadful consequence of being cast into the lake of fire. This verse emphasizes the grim reality that the wicked will have no chance for an intermediate state or a second opportunity. The judgment described here focuses specifically on the destiny of those outside of Christ, underscoring the eternal fate awaiting those who follow the devil and the two beasts. This is a solemn reminder that there are no alternatives or escape routes for the wicked.

The lake of fire awaits those who are not found written in the book of life, leaving no room for soul sleeping, an intermediate state, second chances, or the annihilation of the wicked. This judgment is specific to the destiny of the wicked and it signifies their ultimate destruction. It reminds us that only those who have their names recorded in the book of life will experience the blissful lot of the righteous, which has already commenced before the final judgment.

The lake of fire becomes the final destination for those whose names are not found in the book of life. It is a stern reminder that there is no room for an intermediate state or a second chance, nor can the wicked hope for annihilation. This judgment is specifically aimed at the destiny of those outside of Christ, who follow the devil and two beasts into eternal damnation. The righteous, however, have already experienced the blissful lot mentioned in Matthew 25:34.
